titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
Emil Lorch Papers, 1891-2004
titlepage.author:
Finding aid prepared by:
Thomas E. Powers

did.abstract: Professor of architecture at the University of Michigan; includes correspondence, professional organizational activities files, documentation, photographs, and architectural drawings accumulated during his work with the Michigan Historic Buildings Survey

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Lorch's son-in-law Roger Bailey in 1963. Donor no. 4041

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Emil Lorch Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Emil Lorch was born in Detroit of German-American parentage on July 21, 1870. He attended schools in Detroit, including the Detroit Museum of Art School, then went to work for the city's architectural offices. He next studied at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 1890-1892, then returned to Detroit where he worked and was active in art and museum circles, especially the Detroit School of Art where he taught from 1895 to 1898. He studied in Paris, 1898-1899, and then went to Chicago as general assistant to the director of the Chicago Art Institute, 1899-1901. He was also secretary of the Chicago School of Architecture.

Lorch next attended Harvard University, 1901-1903, where he obtained his M.A. degree in architecture. From 1903 to 1906 he was assistant professor of architecture at Drexel Institute in Philadelphia. In the fall of 1906 he came to the University of Michigan to establish a department of architecture in the College of Engineering. Under his leadership, the department in 1931 was re-established as a separate College of Architecture within the university with Lorch appointed as its first dean.

Lorch was both a teacher and a practicing architect. He designed the Architecture Building at the University of Michigan, the Belle Isle Bridge in Detroit, and the residence of Alex Dow in Barton Hills. He was also professionally involved. Lorch served on the Committee on Education of the American Institute of Architects and was active in the Association of Collegiate Schools of Architecture and the Michigan Society of Architects. During his career, Lorch corresponded with all the leading figures in academic architectural education, including Roy Jones, Warren P. Laird., and J. B. Robinson. He also was a leading figure in the movement for licensing architects in Michigan, 1915-1917, and served nationally in this movement through the 1930s via the A.I.A.'s Committee on Registration.

After his retirement from the university in July 1940, Lorch devoted himself almost entirely to preserving Michigan's historic buildings. This interest had been fired originally by the Historic American Buildings Survey of the 1930s on whose advisory committee he served and whose records (Midwest District) form a part of this collection. He was active in the restoration projects of Mackinac Island and other early Michigan forts; and he cataloged and collected information and pictures about hundreds of historic and contemporary Michigan structures.

arrangement.p: The collection has been arranged into thirteen series: Biographical/personal; Correspondence; Published Articles; Architectural League of America; University of Michigan School of Architecture; Notes for Lectures and Addresses; American Institute of Architects; Research notes and collected material; Historic American Buildings Survey; Miscellaneous organizational interests; Historic Michigan Buildings; Photographs; and Architectural Drawings.

scopecontent.p: The Emil Lorch papers are valuable for their documentation of the career of this important architectural educator and for that material about Michigan architecture and historic structures that Lorch accumulated in the course of his professional study and organizational involvement. The collection includes extensive correspondence with many of the country's leading architects, most notably members of the "Chicago School," and architectural educators, and manuscript and photographic documentation resulting from Lorch's involvement with the Michigan Historic Buildings Survey and various restoration projects, including Mackinac Island.

scopecontent.p: The Biographical/Personal series (3 folders) consists of collected biographical information about Lorch and materials that he accumulated about the Lorch family. Some of this material is quite early, dating from 1806, and written in German script.

did.unittitle: "Emil Lorch and the Education of the Modern Architect", 2004

scopecontent.p: Correspondence is the largest series in the collection. Arranged chronologically, the series includes interchanges between Lorch and his university and professional colleagues. This series also includes items other than correspondence, such as reports, memoranda, and speeches. Because Lorch was in Chicago at the turn-of-the-century, he came to know Louis Sullivan and other members of the "Chicago School" of architecture. Within his collection, there is correspondence with W. M. R. French, director of the Chicago Art Institute as well as some letters from Sullivan himself. More important is Lorch's lifelong correspondence spanning forty years with George Elmslie, intimate associate and colleague of Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright, and Lorch's brother-in-law. As Lorch was also a student at M.I.T. and Harvard, Lorch knew and came to correspond with Denman Ross, F.W. Chandler and Warren H. Langford. Lorch's correspondence covers a range of topics, not just matters relating to architecture. For example, there is much lore and information about early 20th century academia, some documentation of the effect of the Great Depression on a vulnerable profession - architecture, the effects of World War I and II on the academic community (especially young people), and official state and professional attempts to save a visible and concrete past via architecture.
Appended to this finding aid is a selective listing of correspondents and subjects documented in the collection. This listing was prepared soon after the collection came to the library in 1965.
Published Articles consists of architectural articles and published memorabilia important to Lorch.

did.unittitle: Periodicals containing articles by Lorch and other architects

scopecontent.p: The Architectural League of America series includes materials from the period of Lorch's most active involvement and consists of executive board records, notes, historical information, and convention proceedings. This series also includes correspondence of Frank C. Baldwin during the period when he was president, 1908-1909.

did.unittitle: Correspondence of Frank C. Baldwin, president 1908-1909
Correspondence of the American Institute of Architects regarding 1939-1945
University of Michigan School of Architecture 1909-1927, 1956

scopecontent.p: The small University of Michigan School of Architecture series consists of budgets and other information about the development of the architecture program at the University of Michigan.

did.unittitle: Papers concerning the development of courses in decorative design

scopecontent.p: Lecture and Addresses is a series of notes, arranged by broad topic, and pertaining to architectural history. This series also includes some information about Michigan buildings.
The American Institute of Architects series consists of correspondence, 1952-1957, and information relating to the Michigan chapter of the AIA.

did.unittitle: Committee on the Preservation of Historic Buildings
Collected information with material on Frank C. Baldwin and the AIA

scopecontent.p: Research notes and collected material is a valuable resource for the information accumulated by Lorch from different sources and pertaining to the history of Michigan architecture and to other related topics.

did.unittitle: Notebook containing sketches and miscellaneous notes on Michigan architecture
Newspaper clippings relating to historic Michigan houses
Grand Portage, Minn. (Description of fur trading posts)
Grand Portage, Minn. (Descriptions of Fort Williams)

scopecontent.p: The Historic American Buildings Survey contains general information about the survey with specific files on Lorch's work with the midwest region of the HABS.

Miscellaneous organizational interests has material from Lorch's involvement with the Ann Arbor Art Association, the Michigan Society of Architects, and the Michigan State Board for Registration of Architects.

did.unittitle: Ann Arbor Art Association; history and miscellaneous
Michigan Society of Architects. "Michigan Architects and the War," 1947
Michigan State Board for Registration of Architects

scopecontent.p: Historic Michigan Buildings is a large series of collected information about Michigan structures done for the Michigan Historic Buildings Survey. The series is arranged alphabetically by county, then by name of city. A significant portion of these files relate to the restoration of the fort and other buildings on Mackinac Island and to the historic homes of Ann Arbor and Detroit, to the Judge Dexter home in Dexter, to various structures in Dearborn, and to the early buildings of the University of Michigan.

scopecontent.p: The Photographs series also collected for the Michigan Historic Buildings Survey consists of images of historic Michigan buildings and is arranged by name of county and then city. The photographs were either taken by Lorch or accumulated by him in the course of his work with the survey. This series includes multiple folders for Mackinac Island, Ann Arbor, and Detroit.

scopecontent.p: The Architectural drawings series (13 outsized folders) is arranged alphabetically by state, county, and city. Like the Historic Michigan Buildings series and the Photographs series, Lorch accumulated multiple drawings for projects in which he was closely associated, notably the Mackinac Island restoration, the homes of Ann Arbor, and various Detroit restoration projects.
